title: 109_s3908
content: The "Oil Independence, Limiting Subsidies, and Accelerating Vehicle Efficiency (OILSAVE) Act" includes a tax credit for fuel-efficient motor vehicles under section 30D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A tax credit is allowed for new qualified fuel-efficient motor vehicles under section 30D of the Internal Revenue Code. The vehicles must meet specific fuel economy requirements and be used by the taxpayer. Tax credit available for new fuel-efficient motor vehicles meeting specific fuel economy requirements and acquired by the taxpayer for personal use from 2007 to 2011. Applicable amount determined based on the section's guidelines. Tax credit available for new fuel-efficient motor vehicles meeting specific fuel economy requirements and acquired by the taxpayer for personal use from 2007 to 2011. Applicable amount varies based on the vehicle's fuel economy, ranging from $0 to $920. Tax credit amounts for new fuel-efficient motor vehicles acquired by the taxpayer for personal use from 2007 to 2011 range from $0 to $1,470 based on the vehicle's fuel economy. Tax credit amounts for new fuel-efficient motor vehicles acquired by the taxpayer for personal use from 2007 to 2011 vary based on the vehicle's fuel economy, ranging from $1,140 to $1,780. Tax credit amounts for new fuel-efficient motor vehicles acquired by the taxpayer for personal use from 2007 to 2011 vary based on the vehicle's fuel economy, ranging from $1,560 to $1,860. The terms 'fuel economy', 'model year', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' are defined for the purpose of tax credits for fuel-efficient vehicles. The basis of property eligible for a credit is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed, and no double benefits are permitted. No double benefits are allowed for tax credits on fuel-efficient vehicles. This means that if a credit is already allowed for a vehicle under a different section, the credit under subsection (a) will not be permitted. Additionally, any other tax benefits for a new qualified fuel-efficient motor vehicle will be reduced by the amount of the credit allowed under subsection (a) for that taxable year. No credit is allowed under subsection (a) for certain types of property or if the taxpayer elects not to apply the section to a vehicle. Motor vehicles must comply with Clean Air Act provisions to be eligible for the credit. The taxpayer can transfer any credit for a new qualified fuel-efficient motor vehicle to a person in the business of selling such vehicles, as long as the transfer is disclosed through a window sticker on the vehicle. The taxpayer can transfer the credit for a new qualified fuel-efficient vehicle to a seller, with disclosure on the vehicle sticker. The transfer can only be revoked with the Secretary's consent, and regulations ensure the credit is claimed once. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new provisions related to tax credits for qualified fuel-efficient vehicles. Amendments include changes to sections 1016(a) and 6501(m), as well as updates to the table of sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new provisions related to tax credits for fuel-efficient vehicles and amortization of intangible drilling costs for major integrated oil companies. The amendments apply to property placed in service or costs paid after the enactment of this Act.
